messages.content: Don't make assumptions about what values to plug into functions. Ask for clarification if a user request is ambiguous.
I donâ€™t have access to your location yet. Could you please share your current latitude and longitude so I can look up which city youâ€™re in?
I don't have that info either.

Iâ€™m afraid I canâ€™t look up your city without some location data. If you can share at least one of the following, Iâ€™ll be able to help:

â€¢ Your current latitude & longitude  
â€¢ A street address or intersection  
â€¢ A nearby landmark or postal (zip) code  

If youâ€™re on a smartphone or computer, you can often get your GPS coordinates by opening your map app and tapping your â€œcurrent locationâ€ marker. Let me know once you have something like that!
Can you try turning on the location service and figuring it out?

Iâ€™m not able to remotely turn on or access your deviceâ€™s location services. Youâ€™ll need to enable or share your location yourself. Here are a couple of ways you can do that:

1. On a smartphone or tablet  
   â€“ Go to Settings â†’ Privacy (or Location Services) â†’ enable Location.  
   â€“ Then open your map app (Google Maps, Apple Maps, etc.), tap the â€œcurrent locationâ€ dot, and read off the latitude & longitude.

2. In a web browser  
   â€“ When prompted by this site to â€œallow location,â€ click â€œAllow.â€  
   â€“ If you missed the prompt, click the padlock (ğŸ”’) icon in your address bar, find â€œLocation,â€ and set it to â€œAllow.â€

Once you have your latitude & longitude (or even just a nearby street address or zip code), send it over and Iâ€™ll look up which city youâ€™re in.
I can't seem to get any of that info myself. Do you have any other ideas?

Here are a few more ways you might be able to pin down your city. Once you have even a rough clueâ€”an IP-based location, a description of your surroundings, a time zone offset, etc.â€”I can help you turn that into a city name.

1. Use an IP-based geolocation site  
   â€¢ In your browser, Google â€œwhatâ€™s my IPâ€ and note the address you get.  
   â€¢ Go to a free IP-lookup site (e.g. iplocation.net, whatismyipaddress.com) and itâ€™ll give you an approximate city.

2. Ask your deviceâ€™s built-in assistant  
   â€¢ On iOS: Say â€œHey Siri, where am I?â€  
   â€¢ On Android: Say â€œHey Google, whatâ€™s my location?â€  
   â€¢ On Windows/Mac: In Chrome/Firefoxâ€™s address bar, type `navigator.geolocation.getCurrentPosition` in the dev console under â€œSensorsâ€ (advanced).

3. Check local signage or clues  
   â€¢ Look for street-sign names, store or restaurant names, bus/train lines, license-plate codes, or postal codes on mail/boxes.  
   â€¢ Note the language(s) on signs, currency on price-tags, mobile carrier name in your status bar, or local radio stations.

4. Find your time-zone offset  
   â€¢ What does your clock read compared to UTC? (e.g. UTC +2, UTC â€“5)  
   â€¢ Combine that with hemisphere clues (weather, latitude-style sunlight) to narrow it down.

5. Describe your surroundings to me  
   â€¢ Even a few landmarks, major roads, company names, or distinctive buildings can be enough for me to make an educated guess.

Pick whichever method you can manage, then share the result. Iâ€™ll turn that into your city right away.
